block.p: Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Fiction
THE RESCUE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $22.95.) A volunteer fireman helps a young single mother search for her missing son, a 4-year-old with severe learning disabilities.
THE BEAR AND THE DRAGON, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $28.95.) Aided by the antiterrorism specialist John Clark, President Jack Ryan contends with sinister forces afoot in Russia and China.
THE SKY IS FALLING, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $26.) A young anchorwoman investigates five seemingly accidental deaths that have befallen America's most charismatic family.
OPEN HOUSE, by Elizabeth Berg. (Random House, $23.95.) A newly divorced woman attempts to rebuild her life by taking in a series of boarders.
DROWNING RUTH, by Christina Schwarz. (Doubleday, $23.95.) In 1919, after the mysterious death of her sister, a Wisconsin woman takes control of the family farm and her niece.
THE SWITCH, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $25.95.) A woman serving as a legendary astronaut's media escort searches for her identical twin sister's killer.
SHATTERED, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $25.95.) A glass blower runs afoul of dangerous people after his jockey friend dies from a fall in a steeplechase at Cheltenham.

THE BLIND ASSASSIN, by Margaret Atwood. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.) The story of two Canadian sisters, one of whom dies in a car crash and leaves behind a science fiction novel that achieves cult status.
FOUR BLONDES, by Candace Bushnell. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) The love lives of glamorous Manhattan women as seen by the author of ''Sex and the City.''
WINTER SOLSTICE, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) As Christmas approaches, five lost souls in the north of Scotland discover the healing power of love.
THE VOYAGE OF THE JERLE SHANNARA: Ilse Witch, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $26.95.) The first volume in a fantasy series.
MORGAN'S RUN, by Colleen McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A British convict, banished to Australia in 1788, finds a new life and a new love.
PAGAN BABIES, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $24.95.) A priest who may not be a priest joins forces with an ex-con looking for her big payday.
FAITH OF THE FALLEN, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/ Tom Doherty, $27.95.) In Volume 6 of the ''Sword of Truth'' fantasy series, Richard is captured on returning home.
A DENSITY OF SOULS, by Christopher Rice. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion, $23.95.) Four young friends in New Orleans are torn apart by treachery and violence.
Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Nonfiction
NOTHING LIKE IT IN THE WORLD, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) The story of the men who built the transcontinental railroad in the 1860's.
THE O'REILLY FACTOR, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $23.) The host of a cable news program offers opinions on what's right with America and what's wrong with it.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author, a sportswriter, tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
SELLOUT, by David P. Schippers with Alan P. Henry. (Regnery, $27.95.) The former chief Republican counsel for the House Judiciary Committee presents an account of President Clinton's impeachment. (+)
I LOVE YOU, RONNIE, by Nancy Reagan. (Random House, $24.95.) Ronald Reagan's letters to his wife, along with her reflections on them.
LIFE ON THE OTHER SIDE, by Sylvia Browne with Lindsay Harrison. (Dutton, $23.95.) A guided tour of the afterlife, by a ''working psychic.''
*NATURAL BLONDE, by Liz Smith. (Hyperion, $25.95.) From Fort Worth to New York City: the memoir of a gossip columnist.
EYEWITNESS TO POWER, by David Gergen. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) An adviser to four presidents recalls his years in the White House.
THE TEN THINGS YOU CAN'T SAY IN AMERICA, by Larry Elder. (St. Martin's, $23.95.) A radio talk show host and ''firebrand libertarian'' speaks out about politics and society.
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of one of them.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
IN A SUNBURNED COUNTRY, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) The author of ''A Walk in the Woods'' reports on his travels through Australia.
ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A collection of autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
*THE UNEXPECTED LEGACY OF DIVORCE, by Judith Wallerstein, Julia Lewis and Sandra Blakeslee. (Hyperion, $24.95.) A 25-year study of the toll divorce takes on children.
Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Children's Paperback Books
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $6.99.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a witchcraft school. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $6.99.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft. (Ages 10 and up)
HOLES, by Louis Sachar. (Dell Yearling, $5.99.) A boy who has been unjustly sent to a detention center tries to solve a mystery. (Ages 10 and up)
DON'T SWEAT THE SMALL STUFF For TEENS, by Richard Carlson. (Hyperion, $11.95.) How to ''keep your cool in stressful times'' and enjoy life more. (Ages 13 to 19)
TEN TIMID GHOSTS, written and illustrated by Jennifer O'Connell. (Cartwheel/Scholastic, $3.25.) A witch tries to rid a house of its ghosts. (Ages 4 to 8)
CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE TEENAGE SOUL III, compiled by Jack Canfield, Mark Victor Hansen and Kimberly Kirberger. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Inspirational stories. (Ages 13 to 19) (+)
J. K. ROWLING: The Wizard Behind Harry Potter, by Marc Shapiro. (St. Martin's Griffin, $4.99.) An unauthorized biography. (Ages 10 and up)
THE WORLD ALMANAC FOR KIDS 2001. (World Almanac, $10.95.) A reference book filled with facts and games. (Ages 9 to 12)
WHICH WITCH? by Eva Ibbotson. (Puffin, $4.99.) The Wizard of the North devises a contest to see which witch will be his bride. (Ages 9 to 12)
BUNNY CAKES, written and illustrated by Rosemary Wells. (Puffin, $5.99.) Max and his bossy sister, Ruby, make surprise birthday cakes for Grandma. (Ages 3 to 7)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Sept. 30, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books. Best-seller lists for children's picture books, children's chapter books and children's paperbacks, respectively, are published in rotation on succeeding weeks; all three lists appear each week on the Book Review's Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles. Rankings for children's paperbacks do not include serials.
